item.title: Suspicious PowerShell Download and Execute Pattern
item.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell download patterns that are often used in malicious scripts, stagers or downloaders (make sure that your backend applies the strings case-insensitive)

item.title: Enable Microsoft Dynamic Data Exchange
item.description: Enable Dynamic Data Exchange protocol (DDE) in all supported editions of Microsoft Word or Excel.

item.description: This rule detects suspicious processes with parent images located in the C:\Users\Public folder

item.description: Detects suspicious activity in which the MSExchangeMailboxReplication process writes .asp and .apsx files to disk, which could be a sign of ProxyShell exploitation

item.title: CrackMapExec Command Line Flags
item.description: This rule detect common flag combinations used by CrackMapExec in order to detect its use even if the binary has been replaced.

item.description: Detects suspicious sub processes started by the ScreenConnect client service, which indicates the use of the so-called Backstage mode

item.description: Detects disabling the CrashDump per registry (as used by HermeticWiper)

item.title: Suspicious Add Scheduled Task Parent
item.description: Detects suspicious scheduled task creations from a parent stored in a temporary folder

item.title: Suspicious Computer Machine Password by PowerShell
item.description: The Reset-ComputerMachinePassword cmdlet changes the computer account password that the computers use to authenticate to the domain controllers in the domain. You can use it to reset the password of the local computer.

item.description: Detects DNS resolution of an .onion address related to Tor routing networks

item.description: Detects the use of Tor or Tor-Browser to connect to onion routing networks

item.description: A rule has been modified in the Windows Firewall exception list

item.description: Setting have been change in Windows Firewall

item.description: Posssible Payload Obfuscation

item.title: Esentutl Steals Browser Information
item.description: One way Qbot steals sensitive information is by extracting browser data from Internet Explorer and Microsoft Edge by using the built-in utility esentutl.exe

item.title: Registry Defender Exclusions
item.description: Qbot used reg.exe to add Defender folder exceptions for folders within AppData and ProgramData.

item.title: GoToAssist Temporary Installation Artefact
item.description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

item.title: Query to GoToAssist Remote Access Software Domain
item.description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

item.title: Process Start From Suspicious Folder
item.description: Detects process start from rare or uncommon folders like temporary folder or folders that usually don’t contain executable files

item.title: ISO or Image Mount Indicator in Recent Files
item.description: Detects the creation of recent element file that points to an .ISO, .IMG, .VHD or .VHDX file as often used in phishing attacks. This can be a false positive on server systems but on workstations users should rarely mount .iso or .img files.

item.title: BPFtrace Unsafe Option Usage
item.description: Detects the usage of the unsafe bpftrace option

item.title: LSASS Access from White-Listed Processes
item.description: Detects a possible process memory dump that uses the white-listed filename like TrolleyExpress.exe as a way to dump the lsass process memory without Microsoft Defender interference

item.title: LSASS Memory Access by Tool Named Dump
item.description: Detects a possible process memory dump based on a keyword in the file name of the accessing process

item.title: Process Access via TrolleyExpress Exclusion
item.description: Detects a possible process memory dump that uses the white-listed Citrix TrolleyExpress.exe filename as a way to dump the lsass process memory

item.title: TeamViewer Remote Session
item.description: Detects the creation of log files during a TeamViewer remote session

item.title: Suspicious TeamViewer Domain Access
item.description: Detects DNS queries to a TeamViewer domain only resolved by a TeamViewer client by an image that isn’t named TeamViewer (sometimes used by threat actors for obfuscation)

item.title: Suspicious Recursif Takeown
item.description: Adversaries can interact with the DACLs using built-in Windows commands takeown which can grant adversaries higher permissions on specific files and folders

item.description: Detects potential PwnKit exploitation CVE-2021-4034 in auth logs

item.description: An application have been remove check if it is a critical

item.description: TeamViewer_Desktop.exe is create during install

item.description: Use IE registry to hide a scripts

item.description: Uninstall an application with wmic

item.description: Detects a whoami.exe executed by privileged accounts that are often misused by threat actors

item.description: Detects exploitation attempt of vulnerability described in CVE-2021-4034.

item.description: Detects when a memory process image does not match the disk image, indicative of process hollowing.

item.description: Detects the use of NirCmd tool for command execution, which could be the result of legitimate administrative activity

item.title: Blackbyte Ransomware Registry
item.description: BlackByte set three different registry values to escalate privileges and begin setting the stage for lateral movement and encryption

item.title: Change User Agents with WebRequest
item.description: Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with web traffic to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server.

item.title: Suspicious Execution of InstallUtil Without Log
item.description: Uses the .NET InstallUtil.exe application in order to execute image without log

item.title: Download a File with IMEWDBLD.exe
item.description: Use IMEWDBLD.exe (built-in to windows) to download a file

item.description: Hides the file extension through modification of the registry

item.description: Use “>” to redicrect information in commandline

item.description: Hides the file extension through modification of the registry

item.title: Suspicious SSL Connection
item.description: Adversaries may employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol.

item.title: Testing Usage of Uncommonly Used Port
item.description: Adversaries may communicate using a protocol and port paring that are typically not associated. For example, HTTPS over port 8088(Citation: Symantec Elfin Mar 2019) or port 587(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018) as opposed to the traditional port 443.

item.title: Disable System Firewall
item.description: Detects disabling of system firewalls which could be used by adversaries to bypass controls that limit usage of the network.

item.title: Suspicious Creation with Colorcpl
item.description: Once executed, colorcpl.exe will copy the arbitrary file to c:\windows\system32\spool\drivers\color\

item.title: Code Integrity Blocked Driver Load
item.description: Detects driver load events that got blocked by Windows code integrity checks

item.title: Suspicious Redirection to Local Admin Share
item.description: Detects a suspicious output redirection to the local admins share as often found in malicious scripts or hacktool stagers

item.title: Delete Log from Application
item.description: Deletion of log files is a known anti-forensic technique

item.title: Disable Administrative Share Creation at Startup
item.description: Administrative shares are hidden network shares created by Microsoft’s Windows NT operating systems that grant system administrators remote access to every disk volume on a network-connected system

item.title: Dism Remove Online Package
item.description: Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool. DISM is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images

item.title: Msiexec Initiated Connection
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Suspicious Msiexec Execute Arbitrary DLL
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Suspicious Msiexec Quiet Install
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Obfuscated Command Line Using Special Unicode Characters
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit.

item.title: Run from a Zip File
item.description: Payloads may be compressed, archived, or encrypted in order to avoid detection

item.title: Suspicious Start-Process PassThru
item.description: Powershell use PassThru option to start in background

item.description: Remove the Zone.Identifier alternate data stream which identifies the file as downloaded from the internet.

item.description: Powershell Remove-Item with -Path to delete a file or a folder with “-Recurse”

item.description: Detects suspicious command line patterns used when rundll32 is used to run JavaScript code

item.description: Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information

item.title: Suspicious Get-WmiObject
item.description: The infrastructure for management data and operations that enables local and remote management of Windows personal computers and servers

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Change
item.description: Detects a Sysmon configuration change, which could be the result of a legitimate reconfiguration or someone trying manipulate the configuration

item.title: Uninstall Sysinternals Sysmon
item.description: Detects the uninstallation of Sysinternals Sysmon, which could be the result of legitimate administration or a manipulation for defense evasion

item.title: Suspicious Process Writes Ntds.dit
item.description: Detects suspicious processes that write (copy) a Active Directory database (ntds.dit) file

item.title: Suspicious Regsvr32 HTTP IP Pattern
item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by regsvr32 when used to download and register a DLL from a remote address which uses HTTP (not HTTPS) and a IP address and not FQDN

item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by devinit.exe lolbin to download arbitrary MSI packages on a Windows system

item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by Microsoft.NodejsTools.PressAnyKey.exe that can be used to execute any other binary

item.title: Procdump Evasion
item.description: Detects uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility in which procdump or its output get renamed or a dump file is moved ot copied to a different name

item.title: Possible DCSync Attack
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to MS-DRSR from non DC hosts, which could indicate DCSync / DCShadow attacks.

item.title: Remote DCOM/WMI Lateral Movement
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls that performs remote DCOM operations. These could be abused for lateral movement via DCOM or WMI.

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-EFSR

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to get event log information via EVEN or EVEN6

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote printing service via MS-RPRN / MS-PAR

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to modify the registry and possible execute code

item.title: Remote Registry Recon
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to collect information

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task via ATSvc

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task

item.title: Remote Schedule Task Lateral Movement via SASec
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task via SASec

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks via SASec

item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks via AtScv

item.title: Remote Schedule Task Recon via ITaskSchedulerService
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks

item.title: Remote Server Service Abuse
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-SRVS

item.title: Remote Server Service Abuse for Lateral Movement
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-EFSR

item.title: SharpHound Recon Account Discovery
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls useb by SharpHound to map remote connections and local group membership.

item.title: SharpHound Recon Sessions
item.description: Detects remote RPC calls useb by SharpHound to map remote connections and local group membership.

item.title: Add Port Monitor Persistence in Registry
item.description: Adversaries may use port monitors to run an attacker supplied DLL during system boot for persistence or privilege escalation. A port monitor can be set through the AddMonitor API call to set a DLL to be loaded at startup.

item.title: Creation Exe for Service with Unquoted Path
item.description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking vulnerable file path references. Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary’s executable to launch.

item.title: Registry Key Creation or Modification for Shim DataBase
item.description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims. The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time

item.title: Registry-Free Process Scope COR_PROFILER
item.description: Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution flow of programs that load the .NET CLR. The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR). These profiliers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the .NET CLR. (Citation: Microsoft Profiling Mar 2017) (Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb 2013)

item.title: Service ImagePath Change with Reg.exe
item.description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services. Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for registry to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code at Service start. Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services

item.title: Service Registry Permissions Weakness Check
item.description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services. Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for registry to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code at Service start. Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services

item.title: Winlogon Notify Key Logon Persistence
item.description: Adversaries may abuse features of Winlogon to execute DLLs and/or executables when a user logs in. Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.

item.title: Change Outlook Security Setting in Registry
item.description: Change outlook email security settings

item.title: Code Executed Via Office Add-in XLL File
item.description: Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office add-ins to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Office add-ins can be used to add functionality to Office programs

item.title: Manipulation of User Computer or Group Security Principals Across AD
item.description: Adversaries may create a domain account to maintain access to victim systems. Domain accounts are those managed by Active Directory Domain Services where access and permissions are configured across systems and services that are part of that domain..

item.title: New Shim Database Created in the Default Directory
item.description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims. The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time.

item.title: Powershell Create Scheduled Task
item.description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code

item.title: Powershell LocalAccount Manipulation
item.description: Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups

item.title: Request A Single Ticket via PowerShell
item.description: utilize native PowerShell Identity modules to query the domain to extract the Service Principal Names for a single computer. This behavior is typically used during a kerberos or silver ticket attack. A successful execution will output the SPNs for the endpoint in question.

item.title: Running Chrome VPN Extensions via the Registry 2 VPN Extension
item.description: Running Chrome VPN Extensions via the Registry install 2 vpn extension

item.title: Suspicious Screensaver Binary File Creation
item.description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity. Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension

item.title: Windows Screen Capture with CopyFromScreen
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations

item.title: Suspicious Kernel Dump Using Dtrace
item.description: Detects suspicious way to dump the kernel on Windows systems using dtrace.exe, which is available on Windows systems since Windows 10 19H1

item.title: Findstr GPP Passwords
item.description: Look for the encrypted cpassword value within Group Policy Preference files on the Domain Controller. This value can be decrypted with gpp-decrypt.

item.title: Password Cracking with Hashcat
item.description: Execute Hashcat.exe with provided SAM file from registry of Windows and Password list to crack against

item.title: Powershell Install a DLL in System32
item.description: Uses PowerShell to install a DLL in System32

item.title: Suspicious Connection to Remote Account
item.description: Adversaries with no prior knowledge of legitimate credentials within the system or environment may guess passwords to attempt access to accounts. Without knowledge of the password for an account, an adversary may opt to systematically guess the password using a repetitive or iterative mechanism

item.title: Disable Important Scheduled Task
item.description: Adversaries may stop services or processes in order to conduct Data Destruction or Data Encrypted for Impact on the data stores of services like Exchange and SQL Server.

item.title: Overwrite Deleted Data with Cipher
item.description: Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources. Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives

item.title: Remove Account From Domain Admin Group
item.description: Adversaries may interrupt availability of system and network resources by inhibiting access to accounts utilized by legitimate users. Accounts may be deleted, locked, or manipulated (ex: changed credentials) to remove access to accounts.

item.title: Replace Desktop Wallpaper by Powershell
item.description: An adversary may deface systems internal to an organization in an attempt to intimidate or mislead users. This may take the form of modifications to internal websites, or directly to user systems with the replacement of the desktop wallpaper

item.title: Suspicious Creation TXT File in User Desktop
item.description: Ransomware create txt file in the user Desktop

item.title: Suspicious Execution of Taskkill
item.description: Adversaries may stop services or processes in order to conduct Data Destruction or Data Encrypted for Impact on the data stores of services like Exchange and SQL Server.

item.title: Suspicious Computer Account Name Change CVE-2021-42287
item.description: Detects the renaming of an existing computer account to a account name that doesn’t contain a $ symbol as seen in attacks against CVE-2021-42287

item.title: Java Class Proxy Download
item.description: Detects Java class download in proxy logs, e.g. used in Log4shell exploitation attacks against Log4j.

item.title: Abuse of Service Permissions to Hide Services in Tools
item.description: Detection of sc.exe utility adding a new service with special permission which hides that service.

item.title: Suspicious Reg Add Open Command
item.description: Threat actors performed dumping of SAM, SECURITY and SYSTEM registry hives using DelegateExecute key

item.title: VeeamBackup Database Credentials Dump
item.description: Detects dump of credentials in VeeamBackup dbo

item.title: Mimikatz MemSSP Default Log File Creation
item.description: Detects Mimikatz MemSSP default log file creation

item.title: Dump Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
item.description: Adversaries may search for common password storage locations to obtain user credentials. Passwords are stored in several places on a system, depending on the operating system or application holding the credentials.

item.title: Enumerate Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
item.description: Adversaries may search for common password storage locations to obtain user credentials. Passwords are stored in several places on a system, depending on the operating system or application holding the credentials.

item.title: False Sysinternals Suite Tools
item.description: Rename as a legitim Sysinternals Suite tools to evade detection

item.title: Extracting Information with PowerShell
item.description: Adversaries may search local file systems and remote file shares for files containing insecurely stored credentials. These can be files created by users to store their own credentials, shared credential stores for a group of individuals, configuration files containing passwords for a system or service, or source code/binary files containing embedded passwords.

item.title: Suspicious Unattend.xml File Access
item.description: Attempts to access unattend.xml, where credentials are commonly stored, within the Panther directory where installation logs are stored. If these files exist, their contents will be displayed. They are used to store credentials/answers during the unattended windows install process

item.title: Suspicious Use of PsLogList
item.description: Threat actors can use the PsLogList utility to dump event log in order to extract admin accounts and perform account discovery.

item.title: Suspicious NT Resource Kit Auditpol Usage
item.description: Threat actors can use an older version of the auditpol binary available inside the NT resource kit to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability. This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.

item.title: CleanWipe Usage
item.description: Detects the use of CleanWipe a tool usually used to delete Symantec antivirus.

item.title: Advanced Port Scanner
item.description: Detects the use of Advanced Port Scanner.

item.title: Shells Spawn by Java
item.description: Detects shell spawn from Java host process, which could a maintenance task or some kind of exploitation (e.g. log4j exploitation)

item.title: Suspicious Shells Spawn by Java
item.description: Detects suspicious shell spawn from Java host process (e.g. log4j exploitation)

item.title: Suspicious Shells Spawn by Java Utility Keytool
item.description: Detects suspicious shell spawn from Java utility keytool process (e.g. adselfservice plus exploitation)

item.title: Security Software Discovery by Powershell
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors that are installed on a system or in a cloud environment. This may include things such as firewall rules and anti-viru

item.title: Suspicious Findstr 385201 Execution
item.description: Discovery of an installed Sysinternals Sysmon service using driver altitude (even if the name is changed).

item.title: Powershell File and Directory Discovery
item.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from File and Directory Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

item.title: Suspicious Get Information for AD Groups or DoesNotRequirePreAuth User
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings. The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group. Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.

item.title: Suspicious Get Information for SMB Share
item.description: Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as a precursor for Collection and to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement. Networks often contain shared network drives and folders that enable users to access file directories on various systems across a network.

item.title: Exploit SamAccountName Spoofing with Kerberos
item.description: The attacker creates a computer object using those permissions with a password known to her. After that she clears the attribute ServicePrincipalName on the computer object. Because she created the object (CREATOR OWNER), she gets granted additional permissions and can do many changes to the object.

item.title: Suspicious AdFind Enumerate
item.description: Detects the execution of a AdFind for enumeration

item.title: Automated Collection Bookmarks Using Get-ChildItem PowerShell
item.description: Adversaries may enumerate browser bookmarks to learn more about compromised hosts. Browser bookmarks may reveal personal information about users (ex: banking sites, interests, social media, etc.) as well as details about internal network resources such as servers, tools/dashboards, or other related infrastructure.

item.title: Suspicious DIR Execution
item.description: Use dir to collect information

item.title: Suspicious Where Execution
item.description: Adversaries may enumerate browser bookmarks to learn more about compromised hosts. Browser bookmarks may reveal personal information about users (ex: banking sites, interests, social media, etc.) as well as details about internal network resources such as servers, tools/dashboards, or other related infrastructure.

item.title: JNDIExploit Pattern
item.description: Detects exploitation attempt using the JDNIExploiit Kit

item.title: Suspicious Get Local Groups Information
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to find local system groups and permission settings. The knowledge of local system permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group. Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

item.title: Suspicious Get Local Groups Information with WMIC
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to find local system groups and permission settings. The knowledge of local system permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group. Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

item.title: Clearing Windows Console History

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Admission Controller
item.description: Identifies when an admission controller is executed in Azure Kubernetes. A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server. The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster. An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster. For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod. An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials. An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.

item.title: Google Cloud Kubernetes Admission Controller
item.description: Identifies when an admission controller is executed in GCP Kubernetes. A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server. The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster. An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster. For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod. An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials. An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes CronJob
item.description: Identifies when a Azure Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate. Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs. An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.

item.title: PowerShell Writing Startup Shortcuts

This procedure was highlighted in Red Canary Intel Insights Oct. 2021, “We frequently observe adversaries using PowerShell to write malicious .lnk files into the startup directory to establish persistence. Accordingly, this detection opportunity is likely to identify persistence mechanisms in multiple threats. In the context of Yellow Cockatoo, this persistence mechanism eventually launches the command-line script that leads to the installation of a malicious DLL”

item.title: OMIGOD SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript
item.description: Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript to execute any UNIX/Linux script using the /bin/sh shell. Script being executed gets created as a temp file in /tmp folder with a scx* prefix. Then it is invoked from the following directory /etc/opt/microsoft/scx/conf/tmpdir/. The file in that directory has the same prefix scx*. SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including Microsoft Operations Manager. Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.

item.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS New Server
item.description: This detection uses AzureActivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the creation or update of a server instance in an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service. A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server instance to spoof AD FS signing logs. There is no need to compromise an on-prem AD FS server. This can be done programmatically via HTTP requests to Azure.

item.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS Service Delete
item.description: This detection uses AzureActivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the deletion of an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service instance in a tenant. A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server to spoof AD FS signing logs. The health AD FS service can then be deleted after it is not longer needed via HTTP requests to Azure.

item.title: Azure AD Health Monitoring Agent Registry Keys Access
item.description: This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key of Azure AD Health monitoring agent. This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Microsoft Online\Reporting\MonitoringAgent.

item.title: Azure AD Health Service Agents Registry Keys Access
item.description: This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key values and sub-keys of Azure AD Health service agents (e.g AD FS). Information from AD Health service agents can be used to potentially abuse some of the features provided by those services in the cloud (e.g. Federation). This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ADHealthAgent. Make sure you set the SACL to propagate to its sub-keys.

item.title: Potential PetitPotam Attack Via EFS RPC Calls
item.description: Detects usage of the windows RPC library Encrypting File System Remote Protocol (MS-EFSRPC). Variations of this RPC are used within the attack refereed to as PetitPotam. The usage of this RPC function should be rare if ever used at all. Thus usage of this function is uncommon enough that any usage of this RPC function should warrant further investigation to determine if it is legitimate. View surrounding logs (within a few minutes before and after) from the Source IP to. Logs from from the Source IP would include dce_rpc, smb_mapping, smb_files, rdp, ntlm, kerberos, etc..'

This rule aims to detect suspicious processes (those we would not expect to behave in this way like word.exe or outlook.exe) creating remote threads on other processes. It is a generalistic rule, but it should have a low FP ratio due to the selected range of processes.

item.title: Winlogon Helper DLL
item.description: Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete. Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.

item.title: Cobalt Strike DNS Beaconing
item.description: Detects suspicious DNS queries known from Cobalt Strike beacons

item.title: NetNTLM Downgrade Attack
item.description: Detects NetNTLM downgrade attack

item.title: Taskmgr as LOCAL_SYSTEM
item.description: Detects the creation of taskmgr.exe process in context of LOCAL_SYSTEM

item.title: Sticky Key Like Backdoor Usage
item.description: Detects the usage and installation of a backdoor that uses an option to register a malicious debugger for built-in tools that are accessible in the login screen

item.title: Defrag Deactivation
item.description: Detects the deactivation and disabling of the Scheduled defragmentation task as seen by Slingshot APT group

item.title: Admin User Remote Logon
item.description: Detect remote login by Administrator user (depending on internal pattern).

item.title: WMI Persistence
item.description: Detects suspicious WMI event filter and command line event consumer based on WMI and Security Logs.

item.title: PsExec Tool Execution
item.description: Detects PsExec service installation and execution events (service and Sysmon)

item.title: DHCP Server Error Failed Loading the CallOut DLL
item.description: This rule detects a DHCP server error in which a specified Callout DLL (in registry) could not be loaded

item.title: DHCP Server Loaded the CallOut DLL
item.description: This rule detects a DHCP server in which a specified Callout DLL (in registry) was loaded

item.title: Backup Catalog Deleted
item.description: Detects backup catalog deletions

item.title: PowerShell Downgrade Attack
item.description: Detects PowerShell downgrade attack by comparing the host versions with the actually used engine version 2.0

item.title: UAC Bypass via Event Viewer
item.description: Detects UAC bypass method using Windows event viewer

item.title: UAC Bypass via Sdclt
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using registry key manipulation of sdclt.exe (e.g. UACMe 53)

item.title: Shellshock Expression
item.description: Detects shellshock expressions in log files

item.title: Excel Network Connections
item.description: Detects an Excel process that opens suspicious network connections to non-private IP addresses, and attempts to cover CVE-2021-42292. You will likely have to tune this rule for your organization, but it is certainly something you should look for and could have applications for malicious activity beyond CVE-2021-42292.

item.title: PowerShell Network Connections
item.description: Detects a Powershell process that opens network connections - check for suspicious target ports and target systems - adjust to your environment (e.g. extend filters with company’s ip range')

item.title: Credentials Dumping Tools Accessing LSASS Memory
item.description: Detects process access LSASS memory which is typical for credentials dumping tools

item.title: Password Dumper Activity on LSASS
item.description: Detects process handle on LSASS process with certain access mask and object type SAM_DOMAIN

item.title: Failed Logins with Different Accounts from Single Source System
item.description: Detects suspicious failed logins with different user accounts from a single source system

item.title: Mimikatz Use
item.description: This method detects mimikatz keywords in different Eventlogs (some of them only appear in older Mimikatz version that are however still used by different threat groups)

item.title: Relevant Anti-Virus Event
item.description: This detection method points out highly relevant Antivirus events

item.title: Account Tampering - Suspicious Failed Logon Reasons
item.description: This method uses uncommon error codes on failed logons to determine suspicious activity and tampering with accounts that have been disabled or somehow restricted.

item.title: Abusing Windows Telemetry For Persistence
item.description: Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections. This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run. The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.

item.title: Abusing Windows Telemetry For Persistence
item.description: Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections. This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run. The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.

item.title: Accessing WinAPI in PowerShell
item.description: Detecting use WinAPI Functions in PowerShell

item.title: Accessing WinAPI in PowerShell for Credentials Dumping
item.description: Detects Accessing to lsass.exe by Powershell

item.title: Activity from Anonymous IP Addresses
item.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when users were active from an IP address that has been identified as an anonymous proxy IP address.

item.title: Activity from Infrequent Country
item.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when an activity occurs from a location that wasn’t recently or never visited by any user in the organization.

item.title: Activity from Suspicious IP Addresses
item.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported users were active from an IP address identified as risky by Microsoft Threat Intelligence. These IP addresses are involved in malicious activities, such as Botnet C&C, and may indicate compromised account.

item.title: Activity Performed by Terminated User
item.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported for users whose account were terminated in Azure AD, but still perform activities in other platforms such as AWS or Salesforce. This is especially relevant for users who use another account to manage resources, since these accounts are often not terminated when a user leaves the company.

item.title: ADFS Database Named Pipe Connection
item.description: Detects suspicious local connections via a named pipe to the AD FS configuration database (Windows Internal Database). Used to access information such as the AD FS configuration settings which contains sensitive information used to sign SAML tokens.

item.title: AnyDesk Silent Installation
item.description: AnyDesk Remote Desktop silent installation can be used by attacker to gain remote access.

item.title: APT PRIVATELOG Image Load Pattern
item.description: Detects an image load pattern as seen when a tool named PRIVATELOG is used and rarely observed under legitimate circumstances

item.title: Arbitrary Shell Command Execution Via Settingcontent-Ms
item.description: The .SettingContent-ms file type was introduced in Windows 10 and allows a user to create “shortcuts” to various Windows 10 setting pages. These files are simply XML and contain paths to various Windows 10 settings binaries.

item.title: Atbroker Registry Change
item.description: Detects creation/modification of Assisitive Technology applications and persistence with usage of ATs

item.title: Atera Agent Installation
item.description: Detects successful installation of Atera Remote Monitoring & Management (RMM) agent as recently found to be used by Conti operators

item.title: Audio Capture
item.description: Detects attempts to record audio with arecord utility

item.title: AWL Bypass with Winrm.vbs and Malicious WsmPty.xsl/WsmTxt.xsl
item.description: Detects execution of attacker-controlled WsmPty.xsl or WsmTxt.xsl via winrm.vbs and copied cscript.exe (can be renamed)

item.title: AWS EC2 VM Export Failure
item.description: An attempt to export an AWS EC2 instance has been detected. A VM Export might indicate an attempt to extract information from an instance.

item.title: AWS Glue Development Endpoint Activity
item.description: Detects possible suspicious glue development endpoint activity.

item.title: Azure Application Credential Modified
item.description: Identifies when a application credential is modified.

item.title: Azure Application Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a application is deleted in Azure.

item.title: Azure Container Registry Created or Deleted
item.description: Detects when a Container Registry is created or deleted.

item.title: Azure Device No Longer Managed or Compliant
item.description: Identifies when a device in azure is no longer managed or compliant

item.title: Azure Device or Configuration Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a device or device configuration in azure is modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure DNS Zone Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when DNS zone is modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Domain Federation Settings Modified
item.description: Identifies when an user or application modified the federation settings on the domain.

item.title: Azure Firewall Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a firewall is created, modified, or deleted.

item.title: Azure Firewall Rule Collection Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when Rule Collections (Application, NAT, and Network) is being modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Firewall Rule Configuration Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a Firewall Rule Configuration is Modified or Deleted.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Cluster Created or Deleted
item.description: Detects when a Azure Kubernetes Cluster is created or deleted.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Network Policy Change
item.description: Identifies when a Azure Kubernetes network policy is modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes RoleBinding/ClusterRoleBinding Modified and Deleted
item.description: Detects the creation or patching of potential malicious RoleBinding/ClusterRoleBinding.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Secret or Config Object Access
item.description: Identifies when a Kubernetes account access a sensitive objects such as configmaps or secrets.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Sensitive Role Access
item.description: Identifies when ClusterRoles/Roles are being modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Kubernetes Service Account Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a service account is modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Network Firewall Policy Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a Firewall Policy is Modified or Deleted.

item.title: Azure Network Security Configuration Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a network security configuration is modified or deleted.

item.title: Azure Owner Removed From Application or Service Principal
item.description: Identifies when a owner is was removed from a application or service principal in Azure.

item.title: Azure Point-to-site VPN Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a Point-to-site VPN is Modified or Deleted.

item.title: Azure Service Principal Created
item.description: Identifies when a service principal is created in Azure.

item.title: Azure Service Principal Removed
item.description: Identifies when a service principal was removed in Azure.

item.title: Azure Virtual Network Device Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a virtual network device is being modified or deleted. This can be a network interface, network virtual appliance, virtual hub, or virtual router.

item.title: Azure Virtual Network Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a Virtual Network is modified or deleted in Azure.

item.title: Azure VPN Connection Modified or Deleted
item.description: Identifies when a VPN connection is modified or deleted.

item.title: BabyShark Agent Pattern
item.description: Detects Baby Shark C2 Framework communication patterns

item.title: Bitsadmin Download
item.description: Detects usage of bitsadmin downloading a file

item.title: Bitsadmin to Uncommon TLD
item.description: Detects Bitsadmin connections to domains with uncommon TLDs - https://twitter.com/jhencinski/status/1102695118455349248 - https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Investigating+Microsoft+BITS+Activity/23281/

item.title: Bypass UAC Using DelegateExecute
item.description: Bypasses User Account Control using a fileless method

item.title: Bypass UAC Using Event Viewer
item.description: Bypasses User Account Control using Event Viewer and a relevant Windows Registry modification

item.title: Bypass UAC Using SilentCleanup Task
item.description: There is an auto-elevated task called SilentCleanup located in %windir%\system32\cleanmgr.exe This can be abused to elevate any file with Administrator privileges without prompting UAC

item.title: CACTUSTORCH Remote Thread Creation
item.description: Detects remote thread creation from CACTUSTORCH as described in references.

item.title: Changing RDP Port to Non Standard Number
item.description: Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems. It allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user interface on a remote system. Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).

item.title: Cisco ASA FTD Exploit CVE-2020-3452
item.description: Detects exploitation attempts on Cisco ASA FTD systems exploiting CVE-2020-3452 with a status code of 200 (sccessful exploitation)

item.title: Clipboard Collection of Image Data with Xclip Tool
item.description: Detects attempts to collect image data stored in the clipboard from users with the usage of xclip tool. Xclip has to be installed. Highly recommended using rule on servers, due to high usage of clipboard utilities on user workstations.

item.title: Cmd Stream Redirection
item.description: Detects the redirection of an output stream of / within a Windows command line session

item.title: CobaltStrike BOF Injection Pattern
item.description: Detects a typical pattern of a CobaltStrike BOF which inject into other processes

item.title: CobaltStrike Load by Rundll32
item.description: Rundll32 can be use by Cobalt Strike with StartW function to load DLLs from the command line.

item.title: CobaltStrike Malformed UAs in Malleable Profiles
item.description: Detects different malformed user agents used in Malleable Profiles used with Cobalt Strike

item.title: CobaltStrike Named Pipe
item.description: Detects the creation of a named pipe as used by CobaltStrike

item.title: CobaltStrike Service Installations
item.description: Detects known malicious service installs that appear in cases in which a Cobalt Strike beacon elevates privileges or lateral movement

item.title: CobaltStrike Service Installations in Registry
item.description: Detects known malicious service installs that appear in cases in which a Cobalt Strike beacon elevates privileges or lateral movement. We can also catch this by system log 7045 (https://github.com/SigmaHQ/sigma/blob/master/rules/windows/builtin/win_cobaltstrike_service_installs.yml) In some SIEM you can catch those events also in HKLM\System\ControlSet001\Services or HKLM\System\ControlSet002\Services, however, this rule is based on a regular sysmon’s events.

item.title: Code Injection by ld.so Preload
item.description: Detects the ld.so preload persistence file. See man ld.so for more information.

item.title: Communication To Mega.nz
item.description: Detects an executable accessing mega.co.nz, which could be a sign of forbidden file sharing use of data exfiltration by malicious actors

item.title: CreateDump Process Dump
item.description: Detects uses of the createdump.exe LOLOBIN utility to dump process memory

item.title: Creation of a Local Hidden User Account by Registry
item.description: Sysmon registry detection of a local hidden user account.

item.title: Credential Dumping by Pypykatz
item.description: Detects LSASS process access by pypykatz for credential dumping.

item.title: Credential Dumping Tools Service Execution
item.description: Detects well-known credential dumping tools execution via service execution events

item.title: Cscript Visual Basic Script Execution
item.description: Adversaries may abuse Visual Basic (VB) for execution

item.title: CVE-2021-1675 Print Spooler Exploitation
item.description: Detects driver load events print service operational log that are a sign of successful exploitation attempts against print spooler vulnerability CVE-2021-1675

item.title: CVE-2021-1675 Print Spooler Exploitation Filename Pattern
item.description: Detects the default filename used in PoC code against print spooler vulnerability CVE-2021-1675

item.title: CVE-2021-1675 Print Spooler Exploitation IPC Access
item.description: Detects remote printer driver load from Detailed File Share in Security logs that are a sign of successful exploitation attempts against print spooler vulnerability CVE-2021-1675 and CVE-2021-34527

item.title: CVE-2021-26858 Exchange Exploitation
item.description: Detects possible successful exploitation for vulnerability described in CVE-2021-26858 by looking for | creation of non-standard files on disk by Exchange Server’s Unified Messaging service | which could indicate dropping web shells or other malicious content

item.title: CVE-2021-3156 Exploitation Attempt
item.description: Detects exploitation attempt of vulnerability described in CVE-2021-3156. | Alternative approach might be to look for flooding of auditd logs due to bruteforcing | required to trigger the heap-based buffer overflow.

item.title: CVE-2021-41773 Exploitation Attempt
item.description: Detects exploitation of flaw in path normalization in Apache HTTP server 2.4.49. An attacker could use a path traversal attack to map URLs to files outside the expected document root. If files outside of the document root are not protected by “require all denied” these requests can succeed. Additionally this flaw could leak the source of interpreted files like CGI scripts. This issue is known to be exploited in the wild. This issue only affects Apache 2.4.49 and not earlier versions.

item.title: DarkSide Ransomware Pattern
item.description: Detects DarkSide Ransomware and helpers

item.title: Data Exfiltration to Unsanctioned Apps
item.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when a user or IP address uses an app that is not sanctioned to perform an activity that resembles an attempt to exfiltrate information from your organization.

item.title: Deletes Backup Files
item.description: Adversaries may delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off services designed to aid in the recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery.

item.title: Detect Virtualbox Driver Installation OR Starting Of VMs
item.description: Adversaries can carry out malicious operations using a virtual instance to avoid detection. This rule is built to detect the registration of the Virtualbox driver or start of a Virtualbox VM.

item.title: Detected Windows Software Discovery
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to enumerate software for a variety of reasons, such as figuring out what security measures are present or if the compromised system has a version of software that is vulnerable.

item.title: Detecting Fake Instances Of Hxtsr.exe
item.description: HxTsr.exe is a Microsoft compressed executable file called Microsoft Outlook Communications.HxTsr.exe is part of Outlook apps, because it resides in a hidden “WindowsApps” subfolder of “C:\Program Files”. Its path includes a version number, e.g., “C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\microsoft.windowscommunicationsapps_17.7466.41167.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\HxTsr.exe”. Any instances of hxtsr.exe not in this folder may be malware camouflaging itself as HxTsr.exe

item.title: DEWMODE Webshell Access
item.description: Detects access to DEWMODE webshell as described in FIREEYE report

item.title: Disable Exploit Guard Network Protection on Windows Defender
item.description: Detects disabling Windows Defender Exploit Guard Network Protection

item.title: Disable Microsoft Defender Firewall via Registry
item.description: Adversaries may disable or modify system firewalls in order to bypass controls limiting network usage

item.title: Disable Microsoft Office Security Features
item.description: Disable Microsoft Office Security Features by registry

item.title: Disable or Delete Windows Eventlog
item.description: Detects command that is used to disable or delete Windows eventlog via logman Windows utility

item.title: Disable PUA Protection on Windows Defender
item.description: Detects disabling Windows Defender PUA protection

item.title: Disable Tamper Protection on Windows Defender
item.description: Detects disabling Windows Defender Tamper Protection

item.title: Disable UAC Using Registry
item.description: Disable User Account Conrol (UAC) by changing its registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\EnableLUA from 1 to 0

item.title: Disable Windows IIS HTTP Logging
item.description: Disables HTTP logging on a Windows IIS web server as seen by Threat Group 3390 (Bronze Union)

item.title: Disabled MFA to Bypass Authentication Mechanisms
item.description: Detection for when multi factor authentication has been disabled, which might indicate a malicious activity to bypass authentication mechanisms.

item.title: Disabled Users Failing To Authenticate From Source Using Kerberos
item.description: Detects failed logins with multiple disabled domain accounts from a single source system using the Kerberos protocol.

item.title: Disabled Volume Snapshots
item.description: Detects commands that temporarily turn off Volume Snapshots

item.title: DNS HybridConnectionManager Service Bus
item.description: Detects Azure Hybrid Connection Manager services querying the Azure service bus service

item.title: DNS Query for MEGA.io Upload Domain
item.description: Detects DNS queries for subdomains used for upload to MEGA.io

item.title: DNS ServerLevelPluginDll Install
item.description: Detects the installation of a plugin DLL via ServerLevelPluginDll parameter in Registry, which can be used to execute code in context of the DNS server (restart required)

item.title: Domain User Enumeration Network Recon 01
item.description: Domain user and group enumeration via network reconnaissance. Seen in APT 29 and other common tactics and actors. Detects a set of RPC (remote procedure calls) used to enumerate a domain controller. The rule was created based off the datasets and hackathon from https://github.com/OTRF/detection-hackathon-apt29

item.title: Domestic Kitten FurBall Malware Pattern
item.description: Detects specific malware patterns used by FurBall malware linked to Iranian Domestic Kitten APT group

item.title: Dropping Of Password Filter DLL
item.description: Detects dropping of dll files in system32 that may be used to retrieve user credentials from LSASS

item.title: Dumpert Process Dumper
item.description: Detects the use of Dumpert process dumper, which dumps the lsass.exe process memory

item.title: Dynamic C Sharp Compile Artefact
item.description: When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process. Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk. This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

item.title: Enable Windows Remote Management
item.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote systems using Windows Remote Management (WinRM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

item.title: Esentutl Gather Credentials
item.description: Conti recommendation to its affiliates to use esentutl to access NTDS dumped file. Trickbot also uses this utilities to get MSEdge info via its module pwgrab.

item.title: Esentutl Volume Shadow Copy Service Keys
item.description: Detects the volume shadow copy service initialization and processing via esentutl. Registry keys such as HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\VSS\Diag\VolSnap\Volume are captured.

item.title: Exchange Exploitation Activity
item.description: Detects activity observed by different researchers to be HAFNIUM group activity (or related) on Exchange servers

item.title: Exchange Exploitation CVE-2021-28480
item.description: Detects successful exploitation of Exchange vulnerability as reported in CVE-2021-28480

item.title: Exchange Exploitation Used by HAFNIUM
item.description: Detects exploitation attempts in Exchange server logs as described in blog posts reporting on HAFNIUM group activity

item.title: Exchange PowerShell Snap-Ins Used by HAFNIUM
item.description: Detects adding and using Exchange PowerShell snap-ins to export mailbox data by HAFNIUM

item.title: Exchange ProxyShell Pattern
item.description: Detects URL patterns that could be found in ProxyShell exploitation attempts against Exchange servers (failed and successful)

item.title: Exchange Set OabVirtualDirectory ExternalUrl Property
item.description: Rule to detect an adversary setting OabVirtualDirectory External URL property to a script in Exchange Management log

item.title: Execute From Alternate Data Streams
item.description: Adversaries may use NTFS file attributes to hide their malicious data in order to evade detection

item.title: Execute Invoke-command on Remote Host
item.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote systems using Windows Remote Management (WinRM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

item.title: Execution DLL of Choice Using WAB.EXE
item.description: This rule detects that the path to the DLL written in the registry is different from the default one. Launched WAB.exe tries to load the DLL from Registry.

item.title: Execution in Outlook Temp Folder
item.description: Detects a suspicious program execution in Outlook temp folder

item.title: Execution of Suspicious File Type Extension
item.description: Checks whether the image specified in a process creation event doesn’t refer to an .exe file (caused by process ghosting or other unorthodox methods to start a process)

item.description: Detects Execution via SyncInvoke in CL_Invocation.ps1 module

item.description: Detects Execution via SyncInvoke in CL_Invocation.ps1 module

item.title: Execution via CL_Invocation.ps1 (2 Lines)

item.description: Detects Execution via runAfterCancelProcess in CL_Mutexverifiers.ps1 module

item.description: Detects Execution via runAfterCancelProcess in CL_Mutexverifiers.ps1 module

item.title: Execution via CL_Mutexverifiers.ps1 (2 Lines)
item.description: Detects Execution via runAfterCancelProcess in CL_Mutexverifiers.ps1 module

item.description: Detects the exploitation of the Wazuh RCE vulnerability described in CVE-2021-26814

item.title: Failed MSExchange Transport Agent Installation
item.description: Detects a failed installation of a Exchange Transport Agent

item.title: Finger.exe Suspicious Invocation
item.description: Detects suspicious aged finger.exe tool execution often used in malware attacks nowadays

item.title: Format.com FileSystem LOLBIN
item.description: Detects the execution of format.com with a suspicious filesystem selection that could indicate a defense evasion activity in which format.com is used to load malicious DLL files or other programs

item.title: Fsutil Behavior Set SymlinkEvaluation
item.description: A symbolic link is a type of file that contains a reference to another file. This is probably done to make sure that the ransomware is able to follow shortcuts on the machine in order to find the original file to encrypt

item.description: Detects artefacts associated with activity group GALLIUM - Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center indicators released in December 2019.

item.title: Indicator Removal on Host - Clear Mac System Logs

item.description: Detects failed logins with multiple invalid domain accounts from a single source system using the NTLM protocol.

item.description: Detects failed logins with multiple invalid domain accounts from a single source system using the Kerberos protocol.

item.description: Detects Obfuscated use of Clip.exe to execute PowerShell

item.title: Monitoring For Persistence Via BITS
item.description: BITS will allow you to schedule a command to execute after a successful download to notify you that the job is finished. When the job runs on the system the command specified in the BITS job will be executed. This can be abused by actors to create a backdoor within the system and for persistence. It will be chained in a BITS job to schedule the download of malware/additional binaries and execute the program after being downloaded

item.title: Monitoring Winget For LOLbin Execution
item.description: Adversaries can abuse winget to download payloads remotely and execute them without touching disk. Winget will be included by default in Windows 10 and is already available in Windows 10 insider programs. The manifest option enables you to install an application by passing in a YAML file directly to the client. Winget can be used to download and install exe’s, msi, msix files later.

item.title: PetitPotam Suspicious Kerberos TGT Request
item.description: Detect suspicious Kerberos TGT requests. Once an attacer obtains a computer certificate by abusing Active Directory Certificate Services in combination with PetitPotam, the next step would be to leverage the certificate for malicious purposes. One way of doing this is to request a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket using a tool like Rubeus. This request will generate a 4768 event with some unusual fields depending on the environment. This analytic will require tuning, we recommend filtering Account_Name to the Domain Controller computer accounts.

item.title: Powershell Execute Batch Script
item.description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution. The Windows command shell (cmd) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems. The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands. Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops. Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system

item.title: Suspicious DNS Z Flag Bit Set
item.description: The DNS Z flag is bit within the DNS protocol header that is, per the IETF design, meant to be used reserved (unused). Although recently it has been used in DNSSec, the value being set to anything other than 0 should be rare. Otherwise if it is set to non 0 and DNSSec is being used, then excluding the legitimate domains is low effort and high reward. Determine if multiple of these files were accessed in a short period of time to further enhance the possibility of seeing if this was a one off or the possibility of larger sensitive file gathering. This Sigma query is designed to accompany the Corelight Threat Hunting Guide, which can be found here: https://www3.corelight.com/corelights-introductory-guide-to-threat-hunting-with-zeek-bro-logs

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Without Any CommandLine Params
item.description: Detects suspicious start of rundll32.exe without any parameters as found in CobaltStrike beacon activity

item.title: Suspicious Sc Query
item.description: Adversaries may try to get information about registered services

item.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Creation Involving Temp Folder
item.description: Detects the creation of scheduled tasks that involves a temporary folder and runs only once

item.title: Suspicious Service Binary Directory
item.description: Detects a service binary running in a suspicious directory

item.title: Suspicious Shells Spawn by WinRM
item.description: Detects suspicious shell spawn from WinRM host process

item.title: Suspicious System.Drawing Load
item.description: A General detection for processes loading System.Drawing.ni.dll. This could be an indicator of potential Screen Capture.

item.title: Suspicious Task Added by Bitsadmin
item.description: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute or clean up after malicious payloads. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through Component Object Model

item.title: Suspicious Task Added by Powershell
item.description: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute or clean up after malicious payloads. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through Component Object Model

item.title: Suspicious UltraVNC Execution
item.description: Detects suspicious UltraVNC command line flag combination that indicate a auto reconnect upon execution, e.g. startup (as seen being used by Gamaredon threat group)

item.title: Suspicious Usage of the Manage-bde.wsf Script
item.description: Detects a usage of the manage-bde.wsf script that may indicate an attempt of proxy execution from script

item.title: Suspicious User Agent
item.description: Detects suspicious malformed user agent strings in proxy logs

item.title: Suspicious VBScript UN2452 Pattern
item.description: Detects suspicious inline VBScript keywords as used by UNC2452

item.title: Suspicious WMI Reconnaissance
item.description: An adversary might use WMI to list Processes running on the compromised host or list installed Software hotfix and patches.

item.title: Suspicious WMIC ActiveScriptEventConsumer Creation
item.description: Detects WMIC executions in which a event consumer gets created in order to establish persistence

item.title: Suspicious ZipExec Execution
item.description: ZipExec is a Proof-of-Concept (POC) tool to wrap binary-based tools into a password-protected zip file.

item.title: SVCHOST Credential Dump
item.description: Detects when a process, such as mimikatz, accesses the memory of svchost to dump credentials

item.title: Sysinternals SDelete Delete File
item.description: Use of SDelete to erase a file not the free space

item.title: Sysinternals SDelete Registry Keys
item.description: A General detection to trigger for the creation or modification of .*\Software\Sysinternals\SDelete registry keys. Indicators of the use of Sysinternals SDelete tool.

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Error
item.description: Someone try to hide from Sysmon

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Modification
item.description: Someone try to hide from Sysmon

item.title: System Information Discovery
item.description: Detects System Information Discovery commands

item.title: Systemd Service Creation
item.description: Detects a creation of systemd services which could be used by adversaries to execute malicious code.

item.title: T1021 DCOM InternetExplorer.Application Iertutil DLL Hijack
item.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named iertutil.dll in the C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\ directory over the network and loading it for a DCOM InternetExplorer DLL Hijack scenario.

item.title: Tamper Windows Defender
item.description: Attempting to disable scheduled scanning and other parts of windows defender atp.

item.title: Telegram Bot API Request
item.description: Detects suspicious DNS queries to api.telegram.org used by Telegram Bots of any kind

item.title: Time Travel Debugging Utility Usage
item.description: Detects usage of Time Travel Debugging Utility. Adversaries can execute malicious processes and dump processes, such as lsass.exe, via tttracer.exe.

item.title: Turla Group Lateral Movement
item.description: Detects automated lateral movement by Turla group

item.title: UAC Bypass With Fake DLL
item.description: Attempts to load dismcore.dll after dropping it

item.title: UNC2452 PowerShell Pattern
item.description: Detects a specific PowerShell command line pattern used by the UNC2452 actors as mentioned in Microsoft and Symantec reports

item.title: UNC2452 Process Creation Patterns
item.description: Detects a specific process creation patterns as seen used by UNC2452 and provided by Microsoft as Microsoft Defender ATP queries

item.title: Uninstall Crowdstrike Falcon
item.description: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their tools and activities by uninstalling Crowdstrike Falcon

item.title: Using AppVLP To Circumvent ASR File Path Rule
item.description: Application Virtualization Utility is included with Microsoft Office. We are able to abuse “AppVLP” to execute shell commands. Normally, this binary is used for Application Virtualization, but we can use it as an abuse binary to circumvent the ASR file path rule folder or to mark a file as a system file.

item.title: Using Sticky-keys To Obtain Unauthenticated, Privileged Console Access
item.description: By replacing the sticky keys executable with the local admins CMD executable, an attacker is able to access a privileged windows console session without authenticating to the system. When the sticky keys are “activated” the privilleged shell is launched.

item.title: Valid Users Failing to Authenticate From Single Source Using Kerberos
item.description: Detects multiple failed logins with multiple valid domain accounts from a single source system using the Kerberos protocol.

item.title: Valid Users Failing to Authenticate from Single Source Using NTLM
item.description: Detects failed logins with multiple valid domain accounts from a single source system using the NTLM protocol.

item.title: VBScript Payload Stored in Registry
item.description: Detects VBScript content stored into registry keys as seen being used by UNC2452 group

item.title: VMToolsd Suspicious Child Process
item.description: Detects suspicious child process creations of VMware Tools process which may indicate persistence setup

item.title: Volume Shadow Copy Mount
item.description: Detects volume shadow copy mount

item.title: VSSAudit Security Event Source Registration
item.description: Detects the registration of the security event source VSSAudit. It would usually trigger when volume shadow copy operations happen.

item.title: Vulnerable Dell BIOS Update Driver Load
item.description: Detects the load of the vulnerable Dell BIOS update driver as reported in CVE-2021-21551

item.title: Wdigest Enable UseLogonCredential
item.description: Detects potential malicious modification of the property value of UseLogonCredential from HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest to enable clear-text credentials

item.title: Webshell ReGeorg Detection Via Web Logs
item.description: Certain strings in the uri_query field when combined with null referer and null user agent can indicate activity associated with the webshell ReGeorg.

item.title: Windows PowerShell Upload Web Request
item.description: Detects the use of various web request POST or PUT methods (including aliases) via Windows PowerShell command

item.title: Windows Spooler Service Suspicious Binary Load
item.description: Detect DLL Load from Spooler Service backup folder

item.title: Windows Spooler Service Suspicious File Deletion
item.description: Detect DLL deletions from Spooler Service driver folder

item.title: Windows Update Client LOLBIN
item.description: Detects code execution via the Windows Update client (wuauclt)

item.title: Windows Update Error
item.description: Windows Update get some error Check if need a 0-days KB

item.title: WinRM Access with Evil-WinRM
item.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

item.title: WMI Event Consumer Created Named Pipe
item.description: Detects the WMI Event Consumer service scrcons.exe creating a named pipe

item.title: WMI Reconnaissance List Remote Services
item.description: An adversary might use WMI to check if a certain Remote Service is running on a remote device. When the test completes, a service information will be displayed on the screen if it exists. A common feedback message is that “No instance(s) Available” if the service queried is not running. A common error message is “Node - (provided IP or default) ERROR Description =The RPC server is unavailable” if the provided remote host is unreacheable

item.title: WMI Spawning Windows PowerShell
item.description: Detects WMI spawning PowerShell

item.title: Wmic Uninstall Security Product
item.description: Detects deinstallation of security products using WMIC utility

item.title: Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack
item.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named wbemcomn.dll in the C:\Windows\System32\wbem\ directory over the network and loading it for a WMI DLL Hijack scenario.

item.title: Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack
item.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named wbemcomn.dll in the C:\Windows\System32\wbem\ directory over the network and loading it for a WMI DLL Hijack scenario.

item.title: Write Protect For Storage Disabled
item.description: Looks for changes to registry to disable any write-protect property for storage devices. This could be a precursor to a ransomware attack and has been an observed technique used by cypherpunk group.

item.title: Writing Local Admin Share
item.description: Aversaries may use to interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB). This technique is used by post-exploitation frameworks.

item.title: Writing Of Malicious Files To The Fonts Folder
item.description: Monitors for the hiding possible malicious files in the C:\Windows\Fonts\ location. This folder doesn’t require admin privillege to be written and executed from.
